metadata.title: Hypertension in Older Adults -Take at least two readings, one minute apart. Suggested times are in the morning before taking medications and before dinner –Assess for orthostatic (postural) hypotension in standing position, as indicated by the patient’s history Assessment/Plan of Care
anatomical location body part affected: Cardiovascular system/heart and blood vessels, brain, kidneys, optic fundi
description: Resting (seated) arterial blood pressure (BP) increases with advancing age, most rapidly after age 60, with both systolic BP (SBP) and diastolic BP (SBP) becoming elevated(1)

Seventy percent of persons 65 and older have hypertension (HTN), as compared to 34% of adults ages 45–54.(36)HTN is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD), although there are many other collateral effects as well (e.g., dementia, physical disability, and falls/fractures).(37)The rate of hospital admissions due to HTN-related  conditions increased in the United States from 1980 to 2007, based on data (N = 4,598,488 hospitalized cases) from the National Hospital Discharge Surveys(13)

Management of HTN in persons 60 to 80 years of age reduces risks associated with CVD such as stroke, heart failure, myocardial infarction, all-cause  mortality, cognitive impairment, and dementia(14,15,23)

Consensus is lacking as to the specific systolic and diastolic blood pressure range recommendations for management of HTN in older adults –The American College of Physicians and the American Academy of Family Physicians published a 2017 guideline suggesting the following for adults ≥ 60 years of age:(31) -Target of SBP < 150 in general population -Target of SBP < 140 if patient has history of stroke or transient ischemic attack -Target of SBP < 140 in patients with cardiovascular risk factors, along with initiation or intensification of HTN management –Two reviews published in 2017 recommended different blood pressure goals, continuing the debate over management of HTN in older adults -Authors of a systematic review indicated that clinical trials suggest that a goal of < 140/80 can positively affect cardiovascular outcomes(32) -Authors of an evidence-based  review suggested a target of < 120 for SBP in community-dwelling  non-diabetic  patients ≥ 75 years of age, if it is achievable without “undue burden”(33) -The authors also suggested that it is better to use two drugs to control HTN rather than increasing the dose of one drug -Authors of a 2017 Cochrane systematic review concluded that there was insufficient evidence to recommend a target BP of less than 140/90 for older adults(34) –According to the Eighth Joint National Committee (JNC8) (2014), management guidelines for persons with HTN recommend controlling resting BP values below (<) 150 mmHg SBP and between 80 and 90 mmHg DBP.(14)Therapeutic goals of SBP < 130 mmHg and DBP < 65 mmHg for the general population should probably be  avoided in older adults due to associated complications, such as falls possibly due to orthostatic hypotension(1,3) –The Working Group on Women’s Cardiovascular Health strongly disagrees with the JNC8 recommendations to raise the threshold of initiating treatment for older persons, especially because of the effect on women, who are the majority of the older adult population with HTN. The working group notes that the new recommendations put women, especially Black women, at unnecessary excess risk and increase existing sex and racial/ethnic cardiovascular disease disparities(27) -This group suggests adhering to a BP goal of < 140/90 for older women –A 2015 scientific statement from the American Heart Association, American College of Cardiology, and American Society of Hypertension recommends target blood pressure in uncomplicated HTN of < 140/90 in patients 65 to 79 years old(26)

Antihypertensive drug therapy usually involves one or more of the following: diuretic, beta blocker, calcium channel blocker, or angiotensin-convertingenzyme (ACE) inhibitor, and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBS). Older adults using these medications often experience adverse effects and might not or cannot comply fully with drug therapy.(37)It remains unclear whether antihypertensive drug therapy per se improves ADLs in older adults with HTN(16)

Lifestyle intervention involving weight loss, diet, exercise training, and increased daily physical activity is especially important in the initial medical management of HTN. Exercise training can help to manage HTN in older adults similar to in young and middle-aged  adults.(1,37)Clinicians should monitor BP during prescribed exercise in older adults with HTN so that it remains at a safe level (see Clinical Review…Hypertension: An Overview ; Topic ID Number: T709014)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Essential (or primary) HTN is almost always asymptomatic. Patients who present with chest pain, shortness of breath, symptomatic orthostatic hypotension, dizziness, nausea, or other acute symptoms that could be life-threatening  require immediate medical evaluation –For detailed information on orthostatic hypotension, see Clinical Review…Orthostatic Hypotension ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T908170

Common coexisting CVD risk factors include being overweight (BMI ≥ 25), type 2 diabetes, and a sedentary lifestyle –For detailed information, see Clinical Review…Hypertension, Essential, and Type 2 Diabetes ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709013 Causes, Pathophysiology, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stop the exam and notify physician if patient reports chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness

If an incremental aerobic exercise test on a treadmill or cycle ergometer is used to assess the patient’s BP response to exertion, terminate the test if SBP exceeds 260 mmHg or DBP exceeds 115 mmHg(7)
Exercise testing should be “symptom limited” (i.e., terminate the test if the patient reports distress before the onset of muscle fatigue)

causes: Aging involves decreased physiologic function across all organ systems

Two primary interconnected mechanisms are felt to contribute the most to age-related  disease: chronic, low-grade  infectionand increased cellular oxidative stress. Both have been associated with endothelial dysfunction
Common secondary causes of age-related  disease may be obstructive sleep apnea, chronic kidney disease, and renal arterystenosis
pathophysiology: The hallmark of HTN in older adults is increased systemic vascular resistance, which is associated with arterial stiffeningand endothelial dysfunction(26)

The effectiveness of interventions to lower SBP in older adults might depend on their ability to reduce arterial stiffness–The pulsatile pressure-flow  dynamics of BP are determined by vessel wall compliance, pulse wave velocity, and the wavereflections (also called the augmentation index)–CVD risk factors might attenuate the effect of aerobic training on reducing arterial stiffness and maintainingimprovements(4)–Authors of a 2015 systematic review examined the effect of various types of exercise on arterial stiffness in patients of allages with and without HTN and came to the following conclusions:(28)-Aerobic exercise tends to have a beneficial (reducing) effect on arterial stiffness in patients with and without HTN-Vigorous resistance training is associated with increased arterial stiffness in healthy subjects, whereas low intensity,slow eccentric, or lower limb resistance training is not-Combined training has either a neutral or beneficial effect on arterial stiffness
Low-grade  arterial inflammation contributed to increased arterial stiffness to a greater extent than endothelial dysfunctionin 858 Dutch older adults (mean, 67.5 years) with HTN and high CVD risk(5)

Researchers who conducted a 10-year  follow-up  study (N = 4,408, mean age 72.8 years) in the United States found that52% of incident events of heart failure occurred in those with BP controlled below 140 mmHg at baseline(6)

Whether BP should be much lower than 140/80 mmHg in older adults requires further confirmation of reduced CVDmortality and risk-benefit  analysis of adverse events, such as falls related to orthostatic hypotension(1,3)

There is a target range for lowering SBP to improve or delay cognitive impairment(18)–Researchers who conducted a longitudinal study in China investigated cognitive impairment in 294 older patients(80 years of age) with HTN with an initial examination and a 4-year  follow-up.  The decline in Mini-Mental  StateExamination (MMSE) scores, as well as the increase of white matter hyperintensities (WMH) and WMH/total intracranialvolume (TIV) ratio, was smaller in patients who maintained SBP between 140 and 160 mmHg. Additionally, greaterbenefits were found when lowering SBP 15 to 35 mmHg compared to lowering SBP < 15 or > 35 mmHg

The link between HTN and mortality might be related to age(15)–Researchers who studied adults taking antihypertensive medication (N = 9,787, ≥ 45 years of age) in the United Statesfound that SBP between 120 and 139 mmHg was significantly associated with reduced risk for cardiovascular andall-cause mortality in those ≥ 55 years. In contrast, no association between SBP and all-cause  mortality was found forthose ≥ 75 years. Also, no association was found between systolic BP and falls among participants in all age groups
RCTs are needed to investigate whether antihypertensive drug therapy exclusive of exercise and functional training in olderadults improves independence in ADLs(16)

Researchers who studied U.S. male veterans (N = 2,153;mean age 75 years) with HTN found that exercise capacity was anindependent predictor of all-cause  mortality outcomes at a mean of 9.0 years follow-up.  The relationship was inverse andgraded;men with the highest exercise capacity had the most survival benefits(17)
risk factors: Age (over 45 for men and 55 for women). Prevalence exceeds 50% in Americans 55 years and older.(36)Lifetime risk formen and women aged 55 to 65 years by age 80 to 85 is > 90%(20)
Overweight or high BMI (25 and higher). Excessive fat around the abdomen, or “centripetal” obesity
Sedentary lifestyle (< 30 minutes of aerobic physical activity per day)
High dietary salt intake (over 2,300 mg, or about 1 teaspoon per day)
More than moderate alcohol consumption (i.e., averaging more than two drinks per day for men or more than one per dayfor women)
Certain chronic conditions (e.g., kidney disease, sleep apnea)

overall contraindications precautions: Notify physician immediately if patient presents with recent onset of nonspecific symptoms (e.g., headache, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, blurred vision) that might indicate a hypertensive crisis or malignant HTN. Exercise is contraindicated in these patients

Observe the following contraindications to exercise established for individuals with known cardiovascular disease or unstable medical conditions(7) Unstable angina Resting SBP greater than 200 mmHg or resting DBP greater than 110 mmHg Orthostatic fall in SBP with symptoms (postural hypotension) Critical aortic stenosis Acute systemic illness or fever Uncontrolled atrial or ventricular arrhythmias Uncontrolled sinus tachycardia greater than 120 beats/min Uncompensated congestive heart failure with symptoms Third-degree  atrioventricular block without pacemaker Active pericarditis or myocarditis Recent embolism Thrombophlebitis Uncontrolled diabetes Severe orthopedic conditions that would restrict exercise Uncontrolled metabolic conditions, such as acute thyroiditis, hypokalemia, hyperkalemia, and hypovolemia Acute stroke or myocardial infarction

Postpone physical activity/exercise therapy and notify physician if: SBP exceeds 200 mmHg before treatment(7) DBP exceeds 110 mmHg before treatment(7) Symptoms, such as headache or dizziness, develop during exercise

Patients with HTN are at higher risk for exercise-related  adverse cardiopulmonary events. Therefore, a medical evaluation that includes submaximal exercise testing is highly recommended prior to initiating a vigorous exercise program, especially for men over 45 and women over 55.(1,7) However, most patients with HTN can safely begin a low-to-moderate  intensity aerobic activity program, such as walking, prior to exercise testing
Antihypertensive medications should be taken at the prescribed usual time to control BP during physical activity
HTN should be controlled before initiating an exercise program, especially one involving resistance exercise training(1,7)
Avoid the Valsalva maneuver throughout examination and treatment
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Document comorbidities and current intervention Authors of a U.S. study concluded that HTN is associated with co-occurring  executive dysfunction in older adults but not severity of depression(21) Authors of a U.S. study found that older adults with HTN and the apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene, a genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and other cognitive disorders, demonstrated poorer performance on executive function and memory tests than those with neither nor the APOE gene or with either alone(22) physical activity/exercise program diet (e.g., consumption of sodium, sweetened beverages, alcohol, and caffeinated products) weight loss, as indicated Lifestyle management usually includes recommendations for(1) weight loss in overweight/obese patients Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet regular exercise to improve cardiovascular (aerobic) fitness and muscular strength smoking/tobacco cessation(23)
course of treatment.medications: Medications Determine what medications have been prescribed. Confirm that they are being taken and whether they are effectively controlling HTN. The following classes of drugs are commonly prescribed for older adults with HTN Thiazide diuretic (usually the first-line  medication) Beta blocker Calcium channel blocker (including the vascular selective dihydropyridines) ACE inhibitor Angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) Antihypertensive medication reduces cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in older adults (i.e., risk for stroke, heart failure, myocardial infarction, cognitive impairment, and dementia)(23) Based on a 2014 systematic review consisting of 31 published studies (15 trials and 16 studies involving a subgroup analysis from a larger cohort), 95,874 participants, and an age range of 65 to 105 years More than 24 agents were studied. All studies used an open-label design or combination therapy to reach target blood pressure. Thiazide and thiazidelike  diuretics seem to provide the most consistent benefits Due to the large variety of antihypertensive agents, doses, and blood pressure targets used in RCTs or observational studies, there is not enough evidence to recommend a preferred dose or agent for older patients Use of either calcium channel blockers or angiotensin receptor blockers was independently associated with a decreased risk of dementia in older adults(35) Based on study of 1,951 patients with using antihypertensive medication in the Netherlands Patients taking all forms of antihypertensive medication were followed up at an average of 6.7 years to determine if dementia was diagnosed Blood pressure reduction in older adult patients decreases risk of adverse cardiovascular outcomes(25) Orthostatic hypotension is a potential adverse effect of antihypertensive medications in older adults(1)  Occurring in 7% of men > 70years Increases age-adjusted  mortality risk (i.e., premature death) Increases risk for falls and fractures Especially associated with alpha blockers and combination of alpha-beta  blockers and diuretics and nitrates For detailed information on orthostatic hypotension, please see the Clinical Review  referenced above Adherence to prescribed antihypertensive drug therapy is reduced in older adults, probably because of side effects and adverse events from(37) drug interactions increased drug sensitivity decreased rate of drug metabolism cognitive decline or dementia(8)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Recommended workup includes the following:(1)
Lipid profile  HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides
Optional  urinary albumin/creatinine ratio or urinary albumin excretion
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of herbal, behavioral, or other therapies (e.g., massage), and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has received physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Has the patient received education pertaining to conservative management of HTN (e.g., exercise, diet, weight loss)?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Please see Risk factors  for factors that could exacerbate or lead to HTN. Does stress and/or anxiety affect the patient’s BP?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms. Pain is an unusual symptom of HTN and should be further investigated
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Essential HTN is almost always asymptomatic. However, a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010 scale can be used to assess symptoms the patient might report (e.g., at their best, at their worst, and at the moment)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in any symptoms of coexisting conditions throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Does patient have difficulty getting restorative sleep? Document number of wakings/night
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder issues, shortness of breath)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any pulmonary compromise related to the use of antihypertensive medications? Document any use of supplemental oxygen Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Any history of heart disease, stroke, diabetes, renovascular disease, or osteoporosis?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of all prescribed medications, as well as OTC medications and herbal remedies (some might raise BP)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient regularly participate in physical activities? Any hobbies and/or activities that the client enjoys that he or she is currently unable to do? Administer a brief physical activity questionnaire
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: If applicable, inquire about limitations and equipment utilizedAsk about family situation, employment status, and working conditions that might increase stress/anxiety
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -With whom does the patient live (e.g., spouse/partner, children, siblings, caregivers)? -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; are any modifications necessary? -Inquire about the levels of the home, including stairs and numbers of floors

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight and determine BMI. Is weight reduction indicated? –Researchers who conducted a study (N = 962 African American females > 65 years of age) in the United States found the risk of HTN increased significantly at a BMI above 23.(2) This finding indicates that control of HTN might require weight reduction to a greater extent than currently recommended(9)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess fit and use of prescribed devices, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance reactions (might be altered by medications). Administer Berg Balance Scale, as indicated
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess breath sounds (should be normal unless the patient has lung disease)
Check pulse for rate and rhythm
Use Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale to assess relative intensity of exercise(7)
Assess systolic and DBP (see Special tests specific to diagnosis , below)

A treadmill or cycle ergometer submaximal graded exercise test can aid in the assessment of the patient’s HR, BP, and RPE responses to exercise (both at baseline as well as after exercise training) and provide the basis for an individualized prescription for aerobic exercise(7)
The 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) provides an objective outcome measure of aerobic performance and can be used as the basis for prescribing a walking exercise program(10)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulses in all limbs
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess gross movement during transfers and functional tasks using the upper extremities (e.g., reaching, pulling, pushing, holding) and lower extremities (e.g., steps, squatting, kneeling, kicking). Administer FIM, if indicated. Is mobility suitable for exercise program?
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess ambulatory function, including synchrony of limb movements and gait speed, as well as posture. Assess safety with dynamic gait index (DGI)Passive accessory movement in the involved joints should be normalAssess if patient has history of neurological impairment
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength using standard manual muscle testing (MMT) and in functional tasks (e.g., handgrip, pushing, pulling, sit-up,  squatting), as indicated to target muscle groups in a resistance exercise program. Testing handgrip strength might be useful for guiding the selection of free weights in a strengthening program. Testing of one-repetition maximum (1-RM)  strength of the extremities is not recommended on the initial physical exam, or considered necessary to begin a resistive exercise program(11)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Ensure that functional ROM and flexibility are present for the planned exercise programAssess deep tendon reflexesAssess sensation to light touch in the extremities
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis(38)  -Do not smoke, exercise, or drink caffeinated beverages or alcohol within 30 minutes of measurement -Rest in a chair 5 minutes prior to taking measurement. Arm should be supported and at same level as heart. Do not talk. Sit well-supported  with both feet on the floor and back straight -Make sure cuff is right size and that the lower edge does not cross the elbow joint. Use a calibrated instrument to measure -Take at least two readings, one minute apart. Suggested times are in the morning before taking medications and before dinner –Assess for orthostatic (postural) hypotension in standing position, as indicated by the patient’s history

contraindications precautions: systolic BP exceeds 250 mmHg or DBP exceeds 115 mmHg
systolic BP fails to rise more than 20 mmHg
systolic BP falls unexpectedly more than 10 mmHg
exercise-related  symptoms, such as chest discomfort, palpitations, lightheadedness, or shortness of breath are reported, as they indicate exercise-related  distress
other: Clinicians should follow the exercise guidelines of their clinic/hospital and the physician’s order

Individually prescribed and supervised submaximal exercise training generally is safe and well tolerated when the exercise program is tailored to accommodate each patient’s functional capacity and subjective response to exertion(7)
HTN should be controlled before initiating an exercise program, especially one involving resistance exercise training(1,7)
Resting BP higher than 180/110 mmHg is an absolute contraindication and higher than 160/100 mmHg is a relative contraindication to performing resistance exercise(11)
Monitor BP on a regular basis during exercise. According to standard guidelines, terminate exercise and consult the physician if:(7,11)

To prevent exaggerated increases in BP during therapeutic exercise due to anxiety or lack of warm-up,  provide the patient with a thorough orientation to using the prescribed exercise equipment and at least 5 to 10 minutes of light aerobic exercise before increasing intensity
Reduce exercise training intensity if patient reports unusual fatigue or “hard” RPE
Avoid heavy resistance exercise for most older patients, especially those with known osteoporosis
Instruct patients not to perform Valsalva maneuver during exertion. This precaution is especially important for patients with a history of orthostatic hypotension

Extend the cooling-down  period and avoid having the patient stop suddenly after exercise, because this might cause orthostatic hypotension (i.e., a precipitous fall in SBP due to venous pooling) and possibly falling due to syncope

Electrotherapeutic modalities are not indicated for treating HTN. Use cryotherapy with caution in patients with HTN, as cold can cause a transient increase in BP; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in BP
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their clinical judgment regarding the use of modalities for coexisting conditions

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Essential HTN/sedentary lifestyle, functional decline in ADLs, poor physical fitness, overweight, increased CVD risk
assessment plan of care.rule out: The following conditions should be ruled out Resistant HTN (i.e., inadequate BP control despite three or more antihypertensive medications) Renal HTN Pulmonary artery HTN Symptomatic coronary artery disease Endocrine disorders (e.g., pheochromocytoma, Cushing’s syndrome, metabolic syndrome)
prognosis: In most cases, proper pharmacologic and/or lifestyle intervention can control essential HTN, although long-term monitoring with periodic adjustments in treatment usually is required(1,37)

HTN might accelerate the age-related  decline in gait speed, even in well-functioning  older adults –Based on a longitudinal cohort study (N = 643;mean age 72 years) of men and women in the United States(12) –Participants with HTN (n = 293) had a faster rate of gait speed decline over 18years follow-up  than those (n = 350) with BP < 140/ < 90 at baseline  –Neither health and fitness measurements nor brain scans explained this association between HTN and the decline in gait speed
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Primary care physician for questions regarding medical release for exercise program Internist for uncontrolled HTN Nutritionist for dietary evaluation and weight loss Psychiatrist/psychologist for stress management
other considerations: The age-matched  BP readings of women are much lower than those of men in younger women, but rapidly increase after menopause to be comparable to those of men. This is thought to be due to the loss of hormones(37)

Lifestyle interventions recommended by the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure(1) –Weight loss to manage obesity –DASH diet –Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes per day)

Additional management of HTN(19,24) –Smoking/tobacco cessation (with pharmacological intervention as warranted by physician) –Limiting alcohol consumption (no more than two drinks per day for men and one drink per day for women) –Self-measured  blood pressure monitoring with or without additional support (e.g., education, home visits); at-home self-monitoring  decreases likelihood of “white coat HTN”

Health literacy needs to be considered when working with older adults with HTN(29) –Authors of a systematic literature review of the various instruments used to assess health literacy in older adults with HTN found that older adults had limitations, especially in management of care and knowledge about the disease –Fewer years of schooling, older age, and greater number of years living with HTN have been associated with inadequate health literacy in patients with HTN(30)
treatment summary: Physical activity –Physical activity is recommended by JNC8 in the form of moderate-to-vigorous activity 3–4 days a week averaging 40 minutes per session as part of HTN control.(14)The American Heart Association recommends 150 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous activity per week(31) –Higher levels of physical activity may help in the prevention/management of HTN in older adults with knee osteoarthritis(39) -Based on a Brazilian study of 136 older adults (average age 67.6 years) with knee osteoarthritis who were categorized by their activity level -In the more active groups, BP was found to either be maintained or to be reduced over the 12 months, whereas the other groups had increased BP

Aerobic exercise training or combined aerobic and dynamic resistance training (COM) –General guidelines for low-risk  individuals in a supervised aerobic exercise program(1,7) -Type of activity: Aerobic (e.g., walking, dance, or stationary cycling) -Intensity: “Light” to “somewhat hard” RPE, corresponding to 11 to 13 on Borg’s 15-point  (6 to 20) scale. Lower intensity appears as effective as higher intensity in sedentary adults aged 55 years and older(7) -Duration: Totaling 30 to 60 minutes of continuous or intermittent physical activity per day. Preferably, more than 5 hours per week for overweight individuals in a weight-loss  regimen -Frequency: Most, preferably all, days of the week –There are few studies of aerobic training in older adults with HTN(37) –Authors of a 2018 systematic review and meta-analysis  looking at nonpharmacological ways to reduce BP in older adults concluded that 3 months of exercise can lower SBP by 5 mmHg and DBP by 3 mm Hg(40)  -Based on 53 articles with interventions described as aerobic exercise training, dynamic resistance exercise training, or COM -The authors found no advantage of COM over other forms of exercise –However, authors of a 2019 RCT found that a COM program was superior to other forms of exercise in lowering BP(41) -Based on a study conducted in Qatar with 69 adults (58±7 years) with elevated blood pressure or hypertension, overweight/obesity, and sedentary lifestyle -One control group and three interventions: 3 days/week for 8 weeks of aerobic exercise for 60 minutes/session, resistance exercise for 60 minutes/session, or a combination of 30 minutes of aerobic exercise and 30 minutes of resistance exercise/session -Although there were other benefits from aerobic-only  and resistance-only exercise, only the COM exercise group had a significant reduction in BP of 4 mmHg

Resistance exercise training –The American Heart Association position statement on resistance training states that lifting weights at a moderate intensity (40–60%  of 1-RM)  is safe and effective for persons with controlled HTN(11) –General guidelines recommend moderate-intensity  dynamic weight lifting, preferably on machines, two or more nonconsecutive days per week(11) –Authors of meta-analysis  looking at the chronic effects of muscle resistance training on arterial pressure in older adults with HTN concluded that resistance training was effective in reducing BP and lowering need for BP medication in the long term(42) -Based on studies involving 96 patients with HTN undergoing resistance training and 104 patients with HTN who were controls -Regular resistance training over 12–16  weeks, 3x/week, with 3 sets of 8–12 repetitions at 60–80%  1-RMreduced  SBP by 7.26 mmHg and DBP by 4.84 mmHg . maintenance or prevention: Weight reduction and control, as prescribed
